lines.content: * Represents a conversational chatbot that provides user interaction through responses.
* The {@code Chatbot} serves as the primary interface for user interaction,
* handling startup messages, and providing a personalized experience. It
* has a name for identification and personalization.
* Constructs a new Chatbot instance with the specified name.
* @param name the name of this chatbot. It is used in personalized messages.
* Returns the name of the chatbot.
* @return the chatbot's name, as provided during construction.
* Displays startup messages to the user through the provided UI handler.
* This method greets the user and notifies the use of any data loading
* @param uiHandler the user interface handler used to display messages.
* @param hasLoadError indicates whether data loading encountered errors.
*                     If true, a specialised error message will be displayed.
public void startupMessage(UiHandler uiHandler, boolean hasLoadError) {
uiHandler.queueMessage("Hmm... there seems to be an error with loading your data.");
uiHandler.queueMessage("Could you check it out please?");
uiHandler.queueMessage("What do you wanna do today?");
* Main entry point and application launcher for the Elsria task management system.
* Elsria is a chatbot that helps users manage their tasks with persistent storage
* and a command-line interface for task management.

*
  • Persistent storage of tasks to local files

*
  • Support for different task types (todo, deadline, event)

* Abstract base class representing an executable command.
* The {@code Command} class encapsulates the possible interactions a user
* can have with the Chatbot. This includes mutating the state of the program
* and altering data in storage. Each concrete command subclass implements
* specific actions while sharing common execution infrastructure.

*
  • Encapsulates execution logic based on the state of the program

*
  • Provides separation between command creation and execution

*
  • {@link ApplicationContext}: Provides access to application state and services

*
  • {@link CommandRequest}: Contains command-specific parameters and data
* Constructs a new Command with the specified context and request.
* @param context the application context providing access to shared state
* @param request the command request containing arguments and other data
* @throws NullPointerException if either context or request is null
* Concrete subclasses must implement this method to perform the intended
* action. The implementation should use the provided
* {@link ApplicationContext} for accessing application state and the

*
  • Should update application state through the context

*
  • Should provide suitable responses to users through the UI handler
* Provides a functional interface for creating a new Command
* The {@code CommandCreater} interface is specifically for creating a new {@code Command}
* Currently exclusively used by {@code CommandParser} to create new {@code Commands}
* This interface is annotated with {@link FunctionalInterface}, meaning it can
* be used with lambda expressions, method references, or anonymous class implementations.
* Parses raw user input into structured command requests.
* The {@code CommandParser} processes raw input from users and converts it
* into a structured {@link CommandRequest} that can be used for creating
* and executing commands. It handles command identification, argument
* separation, and indicates when it receives a program terminating command.

*
  • Tokenizes raw input into command and arguments

*
  • Indicates when it encounters a {@link Command} that should trigger program termination

*
  • First word is treated as the command keyword
* Credit: Written with guidance from generative AI

* @return a {@link CommandRequest} object containing details regarding
return new CommandRequest(commandType, arguments, rawArgument, rawInput);

* Deletes a task from the task list based on their index.
* The {@code DeleteCommand} removes a specific task from the task list based on its

* out-of-bounds. It saves the list to storage after the deletion.

*

*
  • Invalid task ID: Notifies user of non-existent task

*
  • Storage failures: Alerts user about save issues

* Marks tasks as completed in the task list.
* The {@code MarkCommand} allows users to mark specific tasks as done by their
* index (which can be checked by calling the {@link ListCommand}). It validates
* the task ID, updates the task status, and persists the updated list in storage.

*
  • Confirms the task exists in the list

*
  • Missing arguments: Prompts user for task number

*
  • Too many arguments: Informs user of argument overload

*
  • Invalid task ID: Notifies user of non-existent task
* Constructs a new MarkCommand with the specified context and request.
* @param context the application context providing access to shared state and services.
* @param request the command request containing the mark arguments.
*                Expected to contain a single numeric argument representing the task index.
* @throws NullPointerException if either context or request is null
this.uiHandler.say("Woah woah woah, that's too many arguments! >:(");
this.uiHandler.say("Woah buddy that task does not exist!");
this.uiHandler.say("This task is already marked as done!");
this.uiHandler.queueMessage("Okay! I have marked that task as done.");
* Unmarks tasks in the task list.
* The {@code UnmarkCommand} allows users to unmark specific tasks as done by their
* index (which can be checked by calling the {@link ListCommand}). It validates
* the task ID, updates the task status, and persists the updated list in storage.
* It acts as the inverse to {@link MarkCommand}.

*
  • Confirms the task exists in the list

*

*

* @throws NullPointerException if either context or request is null
